title: MMR Vaccine and Autism: Separating Fact from Fiction
author: Dr Nao
description: Learn the truth about the MMR vaccine and its alleged link to autism. Nao Medical offers comprehensive vaccination services to protect your child's health.
cleaned_text: As a parent, you want to do everything in your power to protect your child's health. Vaccinations are a crucial part of that effort, but misinformation and fear-mongering can make it difficult to know what's best for your child. One of the most persistent myths surrounding vaccines is the alleged link between the MMR vaccine and autism. The Origins of the MMR-Autism Myth The MMR vaccine is a combination vaccine that protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. In 1998, a study published in The Lancet suggested a link between the MMR vaccine and autism. The study was later found to be fraudulent, and the lead author, Andrew Wakefield, was stripped of his medical license. Numerous studies since then have found no evidence of a link between the MMR vaccine and autism. The Importance of Vaccinations Vaccinations are one of the most effective ways to protect your child's health. They not only protect your child from serious illnesses but also help prevent the spread of disease in your community. When enough people are vaccinated, it creates herd immunity, which means that even those who cannot be vaccinated due to medical reasons are protected. Why Choose Nao Medical for Vaccinations? At Nao Medical, we understand that your child's health is your top priority. That's why we offer comprehensive vaccination services to protect your child from a range of illnesses. Our approach is patient-centered, meaning that we take the time to listen to your concerns and answer any questions you may have. We also offer same-day appointments, minimal wait times, and a technologically driven approach with a comprehensive app. Frequently Asked Questions - Is the MMR vaccine safe? Yes, the MMR vaccine is safe and has been extensively studied. Numerous studies have found no evidence of a link between the MMR vaccine and autism. - What are the side effects of the MMR vaccine? The most common side effects of the MMR vaccine are mild and include fever, rash, and soreness at the injection site. - When should my child receive the MMR vaccine? The MMR vaccine is typically given to children between 12 and 15 months of age, with a second dose given between 4 and 6 years of age. - Do I need to get vaccinated if I had the measles as a child? Yes, it is still recommended that you receive the MMR vaccine even if you had the measles as a child. The vaccine provides long-lasting protection against all three diseases. - Can I get the MMR vaccine if I am pregnant? No, the MMR vaccine is not recommended for pregnant women. If you are planning to become pregnant, it is recommended that you receive the vaccine before becoming pregnant.
